page.title: 03BUCK'S MILLS
page.content: Buck's Mills,overlooking Bideford Bay, was once a "living village", but now has only nine cottages permantly occupied.The remainder are second homes or holiday lets.It is a small linear village approached by a steep road with woods on both sides.The wood on the righthand side is run by the Forestry Commission.A stream which runs down the right hand side and ends in a waterfall on the beach,forms the boundary between Woolsery parish and Parkham parish.The land rises sharply to the east of the stream and is mostly scrubland and more woodland.A striking feature of the village is that there are no children there.Many years ago there was a public house near the slipway known as the Coffin Arms now it is a holiday cottage.
